Technology (MICT) in clinical settings”

Henrique MG Martins, MD, MPhil PhD Supervisor: Dr Matthew R. Jones
Henrique MG Martins, MD, MPhil

Growing variety of mobile computing devices: Laptop Personal Computers (PCs), Tablet PCs, handheld PCs/Personal Digital Assistants (PDAs), and PDA-phones/smartphones,
Growing variety of mobile computing devices: Laptop Personal Computers G r o w i n g

(PCs), Tablet PCs, handheld PCs/Personal Digital Assistants (PDAs), and

The terms mobile, ubiquitous, pervasive and anytime/anywhere computing are often used interchangeably in the literature [2, 4].
The terms mobile, ubiquitous, pervasive and anytime/anywhere computing
are often used interchangeably in the literature [2, 4].

Lyytinen and Yoo [5], however, suggest that mobile computing should be restricted to situations that increase our “capacity to physically move computing services with us. As a result, the computer becomes a taken-for- granted, ever-present device that expands our capabilities to inscribe, remember, communicate, and reason independently of the device’s location” [5].
Lyytinen and Yoo [5], however, suggest that mobile computing should be
restricted to situations that increase our “capacity to physically move r e s t r i c t e d

Potential and Visions --- VS ---
Potential and Visions --- VS ---

“Realities” and “Challenges”
“Realities” and “Challenges”

Introduction III – MICT Potential and Visions
Introduction III – MICT Potential and Visions

It has been suggested [10, 11] that MICTs may improve ward rounds by:
It has been suggested [10, 11] that MICTs may improve ward rounds by:

(i) making available up-to-date patient data “at the point of care”, or allowing
(i) making available up-to-date patient data “at the point of care”, or allowing

faster updating of treatment plans, leading to better treatment;
faster updating of treatment plans, leading to better treatment;

(ii) allowing access to reference information, leading to improved clinical
(ii) allowing access to reference information, leading to improved clinical

decision-making, and increased opportunities for learning
decision-making, and increased opportunities for learning

Some assumptions/Themes in MICT in Health commentary articles:
Some assumptions/Themes in MICT in Health commentary articles:

a) Doctors are highly mobile, always “on the run” but making important
a) Doctors are highly mobile, always “on the run” but making important

b) Doctors cannot memorize and thus need a computer with them at all
b) Doctors cannot memorize and thus need a computer with them at all

c) Effective healthcare IS, for example EMRs, are in place to be accessed
c) Effective healthcare IS, for example EMRs, are in place to be accessed

decision as they do so.
decision as they do so.

times.
times.

by MICT
by MICT

d) Online access to as much information as possible (eg. full medical
d) Online access to as much information as possible (eg. full medical

articles in a PDA) is relevant everywhere for medical decision-making and enhances medical education.
articles in a PDA) is relevant everywhere for medical decision-making and enhances
medical education.

e) Remote access to patient data could mean fewer visits to real patient,
e) Remote access to patient data could mean fewer visits to real patient,

a) The number of users seems to influence the utility of functions like

b) The numbers of users varies between sites and from 1998 to 2003 does

especially between resident and attending physicians.

Pilots [26]:
Pilots [26]:

a) MICTs create new challenges that are different from Desktop IS
a) MICTs create new challenges that are different from Desktop IS

- no case described implementation processes in hospitals
- no case described implementation processes in hospitals

b) Modalities of Mobility (eg. traveling, wandering, visiting) are not taken
b) Modalities of Mobility (eg. traveling, wandering, visiting) are not taken

into account when choosing device or analyzing data on usage
into account when choosing device or analyzing data on usage

c) Little evidence to support claims about possible effects on work practices
c) Little evidence to support claims about possible effects on work practices

except more convenient info access, preference for link EMR.
except more convenient info access, preference for link EMR.

Research question (Qs)
Research question (Qs)

How, and with what implications for clinical work practices, are doctors and
How, and with what implications for clinical work practices, are doctors and

hospital organizations using mobile ICT?
hospital organizations using mobile ICT?

This was addressed in three ways:
This was addressed in three ways:

1) assessing usage of mobile ICTs in different clinical settings, with respect to issues such as the types of hardware, software and applications in use, the extent and domains of use, user characteristics;
1) assessing usage of mobile ICTs in different clinical settings, with respect to 1 )

3) evaluating the effects of the use of mobile ICTs on clinical work practices, on an individual, group and organizational level.
3) evaluating the effects of the use of mobile ICTs on clinical work practices, on 3 ) e v a l u a t i n g t h e e f f e c t s o f t h e u s e o f m o b i l e I C T s o n c l i n i c a l w o r k p r a c t i c e s , o n
an individual, group and organizational level.

Strategy : breadth (across several groups of doctors in several countries)
Strategy : breadth (across several groups of doctors in several countries)

+ depth (detailed study of departments using MICT)
+ depth (detailed study of departments using MICT)

Research Approach
Research Approach

Research Carried out – 1. Dept. Without deployed MICT - AD HOC USAGE
Research Carried out – 1. Dept. Without deployed MICT - AD HOC USAGE

AMIA Paper
AMIA
Paper

Survey of US and Portuguese Docs usage of MICT - conclusions
Survey of US and Portuguese Docs usage of MICT - conclusions

1) A significant proportion of doctors did not have or use MICT devices.
1) A significant proportion of doctors did not have or use MICT devices.

2) Ownership was not clearly related to either usage pattern or
2) Ownership was not clearly related to either usage pattern or

frequency of use (“voluntary” ownership seems to relate higher use).
frequency of use (“voluntary” ownership seems to relate higher use).

3) Providing handheld computers (“involuntary” ownership) did not lead to higher number of users, higher frequency of use or significant differences in tasks carried out
3) Providing handheld computers (“involuntary” ownership) did not lead
to higher number of users, higher frequency of use or significant
differences in tasks carried out

4) Doctors owning handheld computers alone, or in combination with laptops, used them more frequently than those using laptops alone.
4) Doctors owning handheld computers alone, or in combination with
laptops, used them more frequently than those using laptops alone.

5) Differences in usage pattern proportions (i.e. having both a Handheld and a Laptop PC against having either of these in isolation), rather than demographics, were a better indication of differences in usage frequencies and the tasks for which MICT
5) Differences in usage pattern proportions (i.e. having both a
Handheld and a Laptop PC against having either of these in

Multi-speciality tertiary care facility. 60 doctors ; 12-bed intensive care unit; 87 beds wards ; outpatient clinics.
Multi-speciality tertiary care facility.
60 doctors ; 12-bed intensive care unit; 87 beds
wards ; outpatient clinics.

-MICT: standard laptop PCs with WiFi wireless connection. Attached to a food trolley and could not be removed,

be removed,

Full access to Windows software, 2 hospital systems (full EMR – including all imaging studies, and a drug administration system mostly used by the nurses) Intranet resources (links to departments guidelines and protocols, library holdings and online resources), Broadband access to the Internet.

2 hospital systems (full EMR – including all imaging studies, and a drug
administration system mostly used by the nurses)
Intranet resources (links to departments guidelines and protocols, library
holdings and online resources),
Broadband access to the Internet.

Wireless laptop usage in the department:
Wireless laptop usage in the department:

Individuals can be divided into three groups:
Individuals can be divided into three groups:

“multi-task” users (enthusiastic-use) who browsed the internet for medical information, checked medical and drug reference information as well as consulting the EMR,
“multi-task” users (enthusiastic-use) who browsed
the internet for medical information, checked medical and
drug reference information as well as consulting the EMR,

“standard” users, who used the laptops only to access the EMR “Non”-users.
“standard” users, who used the laptops only to access the EMR
“Non”-users.

Age, gender, seniority and usage of technologies other than MICTs showed no significant difference between the user group and the non-user group.
Age, gender, seniority and usage of technologies other than MICTs showed
no significant difference between the user group and the non-user group.

The “multi-task” user group reflected the seniority and gender make-up of the department, but included predominantly high and medium frequency users, most of whom owned a handheld/PDA (compared to almost none of the other groups).
The “multi-task” user group reflected the seniority and gender make-up of
the department, but included predominantly high and medium frequency
users, most of whom owned a handheld/PDA (compared to almost none of
the other groups).

Patients located in wards on two consecutive floors.
Patients located in wards on two consecutive floors.

Ward: central area (with several desktop computers) from which six corridors of patient rooms lead off. Each floor had two or three doctors’ rooms (with five desktop PCs). The lift (elevator) was located away from the centre of the wards.
Ward: central area (with several desktop computers) from which six corridors of
patient rooms lead off. Each floor had two or three doctors’ rooms (with five
desktop PCs). The lift (elevator) was located away from the centre of the wards.

“Each of the teams has a laptop, chained, nailed, spiked or something to a portable table, which makes it quite cumbersome by the way because we tend to go up and down between the third and fourth floor and you have to carry the table with you or go use the elevators which are painfully slow.” Resident, Team Alpha Source: Martins, HMG, Jones, MR (2005) “Mobility in the Round: Use of Wireless Laptop PCs in Clinical Wardrounds, Proceedings of the IFIP 8.2 Conference, August 2005, Cleveland, OH, USA

Team Alpha (recently arrived Attending, Resident, 2 Interns, med stud)
Team Alpha (recently arrived Attending, Resident, 2 Interns, med stud)

Last year (…) Rounds tended to be more administratively frenetic when we had the laptop with us. There was more a temptation to do orders immediately, there was more waiting for lab results to come back and interrupting a chain of thought regarding the patient Resident, Team Alpha
Last year (…) Rounds tended to be more administratively frenetic when we had
the laptop with us. There was more a temptation to do orders immediately, there
was more waiting for lab results to come back and interrupting a chain of
thought regarding the patient Resident, Team Alpha t h o u g h t r e g a r d i n g t h e p a t i e n t R e s i d e n t , T e a m A l p h a

I didn’t want [the laptop] with us because I wanted folks on rounds to focus on the pieces of information that struck them as they were collecting it … The likelihood was [also] that there would be nothing more than one or two data points on a couple patients that we miss and that would be required for a decision at that point. Resident, Team Alpha

the pieces of information that struck them as they were collecting it … The
likelihood was [also] that there would be nothing more than one or two data
points on a couple patients that we miss and that would be required for a

During observation only 2 out 5 teams regularly used Laptops
During observation only 2 out 5 teams regularly used Laptops

– Team Alpha – Resident was charismatic and decided not to use them
– Team Alpha – Resident was charismatic and decided not to use them

- based on his previous experience as part of team that used them - plan is discussed based on available information before round - laptops seen as bad for education – diluting attention - laptops seen as useful when rounding on large number of patients
- based on his previous experience as part of team that used them
- plan is discussed based on available information before round
- laptops seen as bad for education – diluting attention
- laptops seen as useful when rounding on large number of patients

- Laptops were also not used at other times
- Laptops were also not used at other times

If I’m pushing the laptop around I can’t use the stairs, I can’t carry it with me, it’s hooked up to that desk, (…) I find that when I’m walking around the wards I’m running all over the place so I don’t want to have to be responsible … for the laptop; if it gets damaged or stolen or anything. So it’s not really a benefit. And there’s so many computers available anywhere I am, I’m no more than 5 or 10 seconds away from sitting down at a desktop and getting the information I need. Intern, Team Alpha
If I’m pushing the laptop around I can’t use the stairs, I can’t carry it with me, it’s hooked
up to that desk, (…) I find that when I’m walking around the wards I’m running all over the
place so I don’t want to have to be responsible … for the laptop; if it gets damaged or
stolen or anything. So it’s not really a benefit. And there’s so many computers available
anywhere I am, I’m no more than 5 or 10 seconds away from sitting down at a desktop
and getting the information I need. Intern, Team Alpha

Efficiency and control over plan execution
Efficiency and control over plan execution

the orders are on the computer it
the orders are on the computer it

just makes things run “Because all of smoother if during rounds you come up and say, I need this order done, rather than waiting ‘til the end of rounds to do it, you know you can do it right there. (…) The round’s a lot more complete I think, also, much more efficient.” Medical Student. Team Beta
just makes things run
“Because all of
smoother if during rounds you come up and say, I need this order done, rather
than waiting ‘til the end of rounds to do it, you know you can do it right there.
(…) The round’s a lot more complete I think, also, much more efficient.”
Medical Student. Team Beta

“I want up to date information, I want to see the information myself rather than relying on somebody else’s recitation of it. (..)And then of course I do want to be able to review all the medications and not only rely on what somebody tells me the patient’s on. Because they sometimes are mistaken. (...) [and] I want to be able to implement whatever plan we’re concerned about immediately. I do not want to delay, I want to enter it into the system as we talk”

Attending Physician Style
Attending Physician Style

[With] the first Attending … we’d have more sit down rounds in our team room discussing things. So at that point we would be putting … the orders directly onto our desktops and then when we would round we wouldn’t really take the computer with us. The second Attending … would prefer us to have the computer with us but at that time we were having a lot of glitches with the computers. The last Attending we’ve had, again she seems to be more sit down, get things kind of under our grasp and then go from there. Although we still take the laptop with us. But again taking the laptop with us helps just getting orders done quicker and as something comes up you can order it at that time, or looking again at radiology is useful”. Medical Student. Team Beta

Discussion
Discussion

In contrast to findings of other studies it appeared that characteristics such as age, gender and seniority did not seem to influence MICT device use.
In contrast to findings of other studies it appeared that characteristics
such as age, gender and seniority did not seem to influence MICT
device use.

Benefits of MICT use in wardrounds were not self-evident
Benefits of MICT use in wardrounds were not self-evident

- significant proportion of doctors did not use the laptops at all.
- significant proportion of doctors did not use the laptops at all.

- immaturity (and hence unreliability) of the technology is only
- immaturity (and hence unreliability) of the technology is only

a partial explanation
a partial explanation

Discussion III
Discussion III

4) Active role of users in the adoption of MICT devices.
4) Active role of users in the adoption of MICT devices.

➔ Important because individual users’ access to mobile, computer-based resources is often dependent on whether they bring the devices to the work setting themselves.
➔ Important because individual users’ access to mobile, ➔ I m p o r t a n t b e c a u s e i n d i v i d u a l u s e r s ’ a c c e s s t o m o b i l e ,
computer-based resources is often dependent on whether they bring the
devices to the work setting themselves.

➔ if the purpose of MICT use is seen to be the provision of ubiquitous information resources, rather than devices per se, then users may feel that their needs are adequately met by static devices, providing these are sufficiently numerous and available, without needing to have the device at the exact point of use.
➔ if the purpose of MICT use is seen to be the provision of ➔ i f t h e p u r p o s e o f M I C T u s e i s s e e n t o b e t h e p r o v i s i o n o f
ubiquitous information resources, rather than devices per se, then users
may feel that their needs are adequately met by static devices, providing
these are sufficiently numerous and available, without needing to have the
device at the exact point of use.

Ubiquity may therefore be seen not as an objective characteristic of a technological resource, but as dependent also on users perceptions and effortful action.
Ubiquity may therefore be seen not as an objective characteristic of a
technological resource, but as dependent also on users perceptions
and effortful action.

Conclusions
Conclusions

Evidence from this and other sites in our study suggest that common issues may extend beyond the particular medical setting: - variability of apparently standard work practices, - importance of individual perceptions (and the social processes
Evidence from this and other sites in our study suggest that common
issues may extend beyond the particular medical setting:
- variability of apparently standard work practices,
- importance of individual perceptions (and the social processes

influencing them),
influencing them),

- the role of established organisational routines
- the role of established organisational routines

Evidence presented suggests that possibilities for “ubiquitous information(-rich) environments”) do not arise automatically or instantly.
Evidence presented suggests that possibilities for “ubiquitous E v i d e n c e

s u g g e s t s

p o s s i b i l i t i e s
f o r

information(-rich) environments”) do not arise automatically or instantly. i n f o r m a t i o n ( - r i c h )
e n v i r o n m e n t s ” )

a r i s e
a u t o m a t i c a l l y
o r
i n s t a n t l y .

- especially in the context of current attempts to provide such
- especially in the context of current attempts to provide such

environments through mobile devices, the realisation of these possibilities appears to be subject to significant social influences.
environments through mobile devices, the realisation of these
possibilities appears to be subject to significant social influences.

- Without clear evidence of unequivocal benefits, adoption will rely on users’ beliefs about the value of ubiquitous information. – these cannot assumed to be universally positive.
- Without clear evidence of unequivocal benefits, adoption will rely
on users’ beliefs about the value of ubiquitous information. – these cannot
assumed to be universally positive.
